thread.title: Strong moral case for Adani mine: fed govt
thread.title_full: Strong moral case for Adani mine: fed govt

title: Strong moral case for Adani mine: fed govt
text:
Print 
The federal government insists a controversial Queensland coal mine can help lift hundreds of millions of people out of energy poverty across the world. 
Adani's proposed mine, slated for the Galilee Basin, received another green light from the federal government on Thursday. 
"I think there is a strong moral case here," Resources Minister Josh Frydenberg told ABC TV on Sunday. 
Mr Frydenberg said more than one billion people globally had no access to electricity. 
"More than two billion people today are using wood and dung for their cooking," he said. 
He quoted the World Health Organisation saying this led to 4.3 million premature deaths. 
"That's more people dying through those sort of inefficient forms of energy than from malaria, from tuberculosis and HIV AIDS all combined," Mr Frydenberg said. 
Asked if Adani will be seeking taxpayer subsidies, Mr Frydenberg said it was a "commercial operation and needs to stand on its own two feet". 
He hinted that the company was unlikely to get access to any cash under the $5 billion northern Australia infrastructure concessional loan kitty. 
"This wouldn't be a priority project for us," he said. @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Uber wins UK court case on taximeters AAP
